So we often say
generative AI is the answer,
what was the question?

Generative AI is really an
exciting new technology.
It's a transformative technology.
In fact, we believe it's probably on par

with transformative technologies
like the printing press,
electricity, personal computing, internet,
and even the cloud.
But really what it is, is it's the ability
to generate content.

And whether that content is
blog posts or social media posts
to maybe summarize meeting minutes

or provide sentiment analysis
for contact center calls.

But to be able to do so,
to mimic human behavior,

to be able to have that
near human-like experience

as it generates content, which
is significantly different

from where we've been with
artificial intelligence
or machine learning where it provided
just a specific answer.

And one of the...
You say it's new,
in some ways it's a culmination
of 60 years worth of development.

Well, with the cloud
enabling low-cost compute,

a massive amount of data
and then advances in things

like statistical techniques,
the transformer model now
being used for generative AI,
all of this has become possible.

So there's been this
buildup of new breakthroughs
which has brought us to this point now

where we can do some
absolute incredible things
in organizations.

Well, and the thing that
I would add is data, right?
We've all been worried about data.
We're buried in data.
And generative AI gives you a path out

to actually use that data, use
it productively for, right,

some things you just described,
whether it's,

improve chatbots, call center,
content creation, right?
There's a new announcement we just made
on HelloScribe, right?
And you've sat in the doctor's office

and watched the doctor
type on the computer.

Get the doctor back in
the room with the patient.
So there's some great new capabilities,
but it is about harnessing data.

Yeah, and we get all
excited with generative AI
about all of the foundational models,
the large language models.

People want to run to the end
and start using generative AI.

But it's your data that is
going to make the difference.

And if you don't have a
strong data foundation,

you are really going to struggle
to be able to do anything

beyond, well, clever parlor
tricks with generative AI.

You, really, as an
enterprise, as a business,
need to get to that predictability,
that contextual information,

and your data is going to be
the difference maker in that.

And what I love about that
is data has been regulated

to IT and the back office
as a heavy lifting task.
And now the executive leadership team
needs to lean in to that data strategy.

[Tom] Yep.
[Phil] Yeah,
and we're at this point now

where we've been on this
journey as a company

that's going to become

Well, this
is a transformative change,

just like cloud computing, just
like digital transformation.
And I think a lot of our old practices,

You got to get

you got to get the organization right.

You got to look hard at the

Otherwise, you're

The competition is not

Your competitors are not sitting still.

So be transformative or even go so far

You should be worried about the impact

And Miriam, you have the saying about,

think big, start
small, scale quickly.
And I think that's what we need to do.
You can't fall in love with the hype,

So how do you really think big

But start now, overcome your inertia,

and learn how you can use

what's going to work in your organization.

Well, it kind of
comes back to,

generative AI is the

Only do it
because it's adding value.

Oftentimes we see the just data analytics,

[Miriam] Right, but lean in.
[Tom] Yeah.
Well get going. Be impatient, yeah.

There's a first-mover advantage.
This is transformative.

You got to have a play on it.

All of this stuff is right there.

Pay as you go model,

You should have done it yesterday.

Yeah, and it'll be good

So, and same thing, get

If you haven't

It's table stakes, foundational

And don't just leave this to the CIO.

No disrespect to the CIO, but
this is a business challenge.
I mean, us, as business executives,
have to understand finance,
have to understand people management.

I think there's a need now
for business executives

to dip their toe into the
technology and data water
and figure out what do they need to know.

'Cause to your point,
Tom, this isn't magic.

This is going to be a
combination of the technology,
business process change, people change.
How do you bring that together?

And you can't leave that
just to the IT team.

Well, and as part of that,
we got to look holistically
at responsible AI, right?

You should have had a
responsible AI program

properly in place if you're
already doing AI and ML.

But generative AI, because
of its generative nature,

is going to force you to
really double down on that,

and to understand how you're
mitigating bias from things,
how you're preventing hallucinations
from occurring with inside your systems.
Even toxic results are potential

unless you have the right
structures in place.

And really,
to build some of that,

we talked a lot
about this, the Galloway quote,

it's people
understanding how to use

generative AI, but it's
that human oversight
that's going to be so imperative.

We're not quite at a
place where we're prepared

to completely remove the
human from the equation.
Now maybe you do in production,
but you've tested and tested and tested

with human oversight, you
know, on how it's operating.
And it's a living, breathing thing,

so unlike lots of software
that we used to write,

you test it, it works,
put it in production,
you go, "Great, we're going to move on.

We'll come back and test it
later. Maybe again someday."

No, this is going to be
something where you're going to

want to run use cases and
tests on a regular basis.

I mean, daily, maybe even
hourly in some things,
to make sure that you're in control
and have a good responsible AI.

And, Tom, I love your point,
and Phil, you say this often,

you've got to be careful with
your addiction to prediction.

[Tom] Yeah.
[Miriam] 'Cause you can make data,
and you can use this technology to say
and reconfirm things that you believe.

Right? And so you got to be
careful and listen to the data.
Leverage this to open new pathways

I think it comes back to
a lot of what we talk about

about data, which is over 75%
of the issues we see with data
are people, organization and culture,
and it starts with leadership.

As a leader, are you
role modeling the behavior?
Are you questioning the data?
Are you asking the right questions?

Are you just trying to
confirm the decision

you've already made?
[Miriam] That you already made.

But I think this is such an
interesting, exciting time.

If you're a business executive
now, the potential you have,

but also the obligation you
have around responsible AI.

And it's not even just the
ethics and bias and the such-like.
It's do you know the implications
of what you're doing?

Which is, I think
we're doing the right thing

with Amazon Bedrock,
which is bring the model

into your environment
in a secure environment,
use your data to train that model,
rather than taking your data
and putting it into a public model.
But also this fact that we know
that there's no single foundation model
that's going to solve all your problems,
so having that choice out there as well.

Well, and that's where
Bedrock's real strength
is going to come in, right?

The ability to access these
language models through an API,
and the ability to then pivot and move,
if warranted, if needed,
or to be able to access a new use case,

rapidly and quickly,
just like all of the other AWS services.

Spin it up when you need it.
Spin it down when you don't.

Yeah, and if you want
to build your own model,
well, don't jump into that.

(audience chuckles)
Yeah, bless your heart.
But don't jump into that.

I mean you could be

firstly learn about what
you really need to do
with the technology you have.

But then you've got the

You've got things like AWS
Trainium and Inferentia

to drive the cost of

So, almost regardless of where
you are going in the future,
you want your data strategy set,
and you want to be in the cloud.
You don't want to try this at home.

potentially, in fact, most
likely has better results

500 billion parameters

What I find interesting is

And I don't think it's a choice anymore.
You need to do both.
And the reality is there's so much money

All of that bureaucracy,
how long does it take you

How much time

I think you do both.

Drive out cost of
